qas.question: Was Alaska's Constitution written to encourage or discourage state funds being used for a particular purpose?
Why is the Permanent Fund an exception to the premise of the Alaskan Constitution?

answers.text: political climate of distrust existing during the time of its creation

qas.question: Where is the principal of the Permanent Fund invested?
How much was the initial principal of the Permanent Fund?
How high has the principal of the Permanent Fund grown?
Was Alaska's Constitution written to encourage or discourage state funds being used for an unparticular purpose?

plausible_answers.text: political climate of distrust existing during the time of its creation

qas.question: Why is the Permanent Fund not an exception to the premise of the Alaskan Constitution?
Where is the principal of the Permanent Fund not invested?
How much was the final principal of the Permanent Fund?
How high has the principal of the Permanent Fund shrank?

context: The Alaska Constitution was written so as to <a0_0><b5_0>discourage<b5_0/><a0_0/> dedicating state funds for a particular purpose. The Permanent Fund has become the rare exception to this, mostly due to the <a1_0><b6_0>political climate of distrust existing during the time of its creation<b6_0/><a1_0/>. From its initial principal of <a3_0><b8_0>$734,000<b8_0/><a3_0/>, the fund has grown to <a4_0><b9_0>$50 billion<b9_0/><a4_0/> as a result of oil royalties and capital investment programs. Most if not all the principal is invested conservatively <a2_0><b7_0>outside Alaska<b7_0/><a2_0/>. This has led to frequent calls by Alaskan politicians for the Fund to make investments within Alaska, though such a stance has never gained momentum.
